Authors: Nagano T., Hoshikawa K., Donma S., Kume T., Watanabe T.
Title: Assessment of adaptation capacity of a large irrigation district towards social and climatic changes: A case study of lower seyhan basin in Southern Turkey
Source title: World Water Congress 2005: Impacts of Global Climate Change - Proceedings of the 2005 World Water and Environmental Resources Congress
Affiliations: Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, 335 Takahima-cho, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto, 602-0878, Japan; Regional Directorate VI of State Hydraulic Works, Cemalpaşa Mahallesi, Ordu Caddesi 01330 Seyhan/ Adana, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Nagano, T., Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, 335 Takahima-cho, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto, 602-0878, Japan; Hoshikawa, K., Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, 335 Takahima-cho, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto, 602-0878, Japan; Donma, S., Regional Directorate VI of State Hydraulic Works, Cemalpaşa Mahallesi, Ordu Caddesi 01330 Seyhan/ Adana, Turkey; Kume, T., Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, 335 Takahima-cho, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto, 602-0878, Japan; Watanabe, T., Research Institute for Humanity and Nature, 335 Takahima-cho, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto, 602-0878, Japan
Abstract: Abstract only available. Many large-scale irrigation projects in the arid and semi-arid regions are now facing structural changes. Water management responsibilities are being transferred from governments to end-users; water distribution management of gravity irrigation networks, designed for mono-cropping system, is becoming more complicated by diversifying cropping patterns; and predicted climate change may further bring constraints on water resource availability and management options. Therefore an assessment of the existing irrigation systems' capacity is important if existing irrigation systems were to adapt to social and climatic changes. In 2002, the Research Institute for Humanity and Nature (Japan) and the Scientific and Technical Research Council of Turkey initiated a research project, 'Impact of Climate Changes on Agricultural Production System in the Arid Areas.' Seyhan Basin in southern Turkey was selected as a study area. One of the largest irrigation districts in Turkey extends on the delta plain of Lower Seyhan with a total irrigable area of 133,000 ha. With the water supply from the big reservoirs in the upper stream, gravity irrigation is conducted with water efficiency lower than 50%. However, climate change experiments predict a decrease of precipitation in the upper basin. The plain has potential drainage and salinity problems, which may deteriorate either with saltwater intrusion caused by sea level rise, or with a change of water use in the district. For analyzing the irrigation district's adaptation capacity, we are applying a quasi three-dimensional irrigation water balance model that can simulate the effect of cropping patterns and distribution management on water balance. The model is coupled with a GIS database of soil classes, irrigation networks, groundwater levels, salinity, and cropping patterns. The model is composed of 3 modules. The Water Distribution Module represents water distribution rule, canal capacity, and losses from the canals. The SWAP Module calculates in-field soil water balance. The Spatial Water Balance Module calculates inter-field groundwater balance and drainage flow out, which would feed back lower boundary conditions to the SWAP Module. In the EWRI 2005, we will show possible impacts on the district, predicted under climate changes in the future, with several scenarios of water availability, land use and adaptive management options. Copyright ASCE 2005.
Index Keywords: Climate change; Crops; Project management; Social aspects; Water management; Water supply; Irrigation district; Water availability; Water distribution management; Irrigation

Authors: Nakamura K., Yamashita S., Sobue T., Takehiro S.
Title: Development of SOFC power generation system using segmented-in-series cell stacks operating in low temperatures
Source title: Proceedings of the 1st European Fuel Cell Technology and Applications Conference 2005 - Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Tokyo Gas Co., Ltd., Japan; Kyocera Corporation, Japan; Rinnai Corporation, Japan; Gastar Co., Ltd.
Authors with affiliations: Nakamura, K., Tokyo Gas Co., Ltd., Japan; Yamashita, S., Kyocera Corporation, Japan; Sobue, T., Rinnai Corporation, Japan; Takehiro, S., Gastar Co., Ltd.
Abstract: In recent years, with a rise of the consciousness to global environment, reduction of greenhouse gas emissions is called for not only by the reason of energy saving but by the reason of preventing global warming. To preserve global environment, international cooperation is required and international effort should be considered. In 1997, the 3rd Session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change(COP3) was held in Japan and the Kyoto protocol was adopted to decide the target and the concrete measure against global warming. For the case of Japan, the protocol indicates to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 6%, as compared to 1990 levels, between 2008 and 2012. However, the emissions are increasing at present and achievement of the target becomes a critical subject in Japan. Tokyo Gas, a city gas supplier, has started a research and development of SOFC as a part of energy conversion research in 1989. After that, we have developed a planner-type SOFC generating electric power of 1 kW under internal reforming in 1998. Then, we have shifted to the development of a low-temperature operable SOFC which has a lot of advantages like a life time etc., and an anode-supported planar SOFC which can operate at 750 degrees Celsius was developed in 2004. The generative efficiency of a. single cell stack is 55% DC (HHV) and 10 cell stacks generate electric power of 140W. In this way, Tokyo Gas has established the base technology of SOFC cell stack with high performance for a commercialization. (Part of this study was performed as R&D program of New Energy Industrial Technology Department Organization (NEDO).) Approach For the sake of contribution to global environment, Tokyo Gas, Kyocera, Rinnai and Gastar ware jointly engaged in the development of SOFC based generator to accelerate the commercialization. The joint project group adopted a low-temperature operable segmented-in-series flat tube cell stack. The segmented-in-series multi-segment electrode structure is designed by Tokyo Gas and the flat tube production technology is provided by Kyocera. This cell stack has many advantages of operating in low temperatures by the cell technology and of generating high-voltage/low-current power by the cell design. When the power generation was evaluated in both companies, the performance reached what we had designed. Since the flat tube manufacturing technology is suitable for a mass-production, low cost production would be realized. In order to build a SOFC system with high generative efficiency, it is necessary to reduce the heat loss and to optimize the internal temperature distribution. Therefore, by using the heat exchange technology and the fluid control technology cultivated by Rinnai and Gaster through a gas appliance development, we are finding solutions of the heat related problem. The target specifications for the commercialization are as follows. Generation capacity 5kW Generation efficiency 45% AC (HHV)Operation temperature < 750 degrees Celsius Because high generative efficiency of SOFC is fit for customers who need much electricity, then main target is settled for business market. Results We have developing the cell stack, bundle and the generation unit simultaneously to aim at early commercialization. The present results are shown as follows. ?Cell stack and bundle Power generation of more than 300W using a stack bundle in a test furnace has been confirmed. The generative efficiency is 52% DC (HHV) for a stack, and 49% for a bundle. (Both are tested with H2 fuel and calculated assuming the same performance using methane.) The stable operation of a cell stack for 2,000 hours was achieved. (Operation temperature is 700 degrees Celsius.) ?Generation unit (thermally self-sustainable) Both generation of 3kW of electricity and generative efficiency of 46.2% DC (HHV) have been achieved simultaneously. (It is tested with H2 fuel and calculated assuming the same performance using methane.) In addition, generative efficiency of 44.5% DC (HHV) at 2.4kW was confirmed with CH4 fuel. Conclusion We have started development of a segmented-in-series SOFC generation system operating in low temperatures for commercialization. Developments of the cell stack, bundle and the generation unit are successfully in progress and they indicate results as expected. In the future, we are going to improve the durability and to realize the low cost production in particular. A preliminary generation system will be introduced in field tests in 2007.
Index Keywords: Cell stack; Commercialization; Greenhouse gas emissions; Kyoto protocol; Electric power generation; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrolytic cells; Gas emissions; Global warming; Performance; Solid oxide fuel cells

Authors: Naoi K., Ogihara N., Igarashi Y., Kamakura A., Kusachi Y., Utsugi K.
Title: Disordered carbon anode for lithium-ion battery I. An interfacial reversible redox action and anomalous topology changes
Affiliations: Center of Future Nanomaterials Science, Institute of Symbiotic Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo 184-8558, Japan; NEC Corporation, Fundamental and Environmental Research Laboratories, Ibaraki 305-8501, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Naoi, K., Center of Future Nanomaterials Science, Institute of Symbiotic Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo 184-8558, Japan; Ogihara, N., Center of Future Nanomaterials Science, Institute of Symbiotic Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo 184-8558, Japan; Igarashi, Y., Center of Future Nanomaterials Science, Institute of Symbiotic Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo 184-8558, Japan; Kamakura, A., Center of Future Nanomaterials Science, Institute of Symbiotic Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo 184-8558, Japan; Kusachi, Y., NEC Corporation, Fundamental and Environmental Research Laboratories, Ibaraki 305-8501, Japan; Utsugi, K., NEC Corporation, Fundamental and Environmental Research Laboratories, Ibaraki 305-8501, Japan
Abstract: The authors investigated mechanisms for an interfacial reversible surface redox action and a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation based on LiF with surface topology changes for a disordered carbon electrode in LiPF 6/propylene carbonate -based electrolyte. The electrochemical reaction mechanism that delivers a large capacity was found to occur differently in two potential regions, region A (1.4 to 0.4 V) and B (0.4 to 0.0 V). During the reversible process in region A, a lithium alkoxide (C-OLi) is formed on the carbonyl edge planes as solvated lithium complex of the C-O -Li+(solv.)n (n = 1, 2, or 3). The formation of the lithium alkoxide traps solvents on the edge surfaces preventing further intrusion into stacked graphene sheets, that in turn suppresses a exfoliation and stabilized repeated redox cycles. In region A, a Li2CO 3 and a LiF are formed as an SEI film by the reduction of solvents and LiPF6 making a smooth surface. region B involves three parallel processes, viz., a lithium intercalation into graphene layers, a lithium metal cluster deposition at nanosized voids or pores, and a formation of LiF by disproportionation of the C-OLi formed at region A. Since the LiF is produced rapidly by a proposed repeated cycle, the electrode surface generates a rough anomalous topology. © 2005 The Electrochemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Complexation; Deposition; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrochemistry; Electrolytes; Lithium batteries; Reaction kinetics; Redox reactions; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Conducting agents; Exfoliation; Lithium alkoxide; Solid electrolyte interphase (SEI); Anodes

Authors: Navarra A.
Title: The climate dilemma
Source title: Extreme Weather Events and Public Health Responses
Affiliations: Dirigente di Ricerca, Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia, Via Donato Creti, 12, I-40128 Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Navarra, A., Dirigente di Ricerca, Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia, Via Donato Creti, 12, I-40128 Bologna, Italy
Abstract: Climate has become one of the most topical issues over the last two to three decades. It has graduated from the status of obscure scientific debate to that of a global geopolitical issue. Climate itself is a sophisticated concept that is somewhat different to that used or discussed in everyday life. The basic nature of the globe's climate is regulated by the global energy balance, as are the principal climate mechanisms. These in turn are modulated via the complex nonlinear interactions between the components that comprise the global climate system. These non-linear interactions generate an intense variability in climate that makes detection of small, secular trends in climate very difficult. The increase of carbon dioxide and surface temperatures is now being established as a fact, but the attribution of the temperature increase to carbon dioxide increases is a complex challenge. Due to constraints imposed by the current level of climate modeling technology we cannot perform crucial experiments in climate science. Accordingly we have to rely on a combination of numerical experiments, often with a considerable degree of parameterization of key climate processes and consensus among experts to reach provisional explanations concerning the causes, magnitude and intensity of climate change. Although the scientific research procedure is incremental in nature, the process of data collection, experimentation and verification of modeling outcomes, results in the steady accumulation of knowledge. It is this knowledge on which we rely for drawing conclusions about the state of the globe's climate and that policy makers use in drawing up recommendations related to mitigation of and adaptation to climatic variability and change. © 2005 World Health Organization.

Authors: Neacsu C.C., Reider G.A., Raschke M.B.
Title: Second-harmonic generation from nanoscopic metal tips: Symmetry selection rules for single asymmetric nanostructures
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Max-Born-Institut für Nichtlineare Optik und Kurzzeitspektroskopie, D-12489 Berlin, Germany; Institut für Photonik, Technische Universität Wien, A-1040 Wien, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Neacsu, C.C., Max-Born-Institut für Nichtlineare Optik und Kurzzeitspektroskopie, D-12489 Berlin, Germany; Reider, G.A., Institut für Photonik, Technische Universität Wien, A-1040 Wien, Austria; Raschke, M.B., Max-Born-Institut für Nichtlineare Optik und Kurzzeitspektroskopie, D-12489 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Second-harmonic generation (SHG) from individual nanoscopic metal tips has been investigated. Compared to both planar interfaces, as well as spherical or ellipsoidal nanoparticles, very different polarization selection rules and SH-emission directions result. As a partially asymmetric nanostructure the tip allows for the distinction of otherwise inseparable local surface and nonlocal bulk second-harmonic polarizations. This provides opportunities for second-harmonic investigations of nanoparticles and in scattering-type near field microscopy. © 2005 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Neeck S.P., Gay C.J.
Title: NASA plans for exploration of the earth-sun system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Science Mission Directorate, NASA Headquarters, Washington, DC 20546, United States
Authors with affiliations: Neeck, S.P., Science Mission Directorate, NASA Headquarters, Washington, DC 20546, United States; Gay, C.J., Science Mission Directorate, NASA Headquarters, Washington, DC 20546, United States
Abstract: NASA's Science Mission Directorate's Earth-Sun System Division (ESSD) uses the unique vantage point of space to understand and explore Earth and the Sun. The relationship between the Sun and the Earth is at the heart of a complex, dynamic system that researchers do not yet fully understand. The Earth-Sun system is comprised of diverse components that interact in complex ways, requiring unique capabilities for characterizing, understanding, and predicting change. Therefore, researchers need to understand the Sun, the heliosphere, and Earth's atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere as a single connected system. At the center of the solar system is the Sun, a magnetically variable star. This variability has impacts on life and technology that are felt here on Earth and throughout the solar system. NASA is working to understand this planetary system because it is the only star-planet system researchers can investigate in detail. Using NASA's view from space to study the Earth-Sun system, researchers also can better predict critical changes to Earth and its space environment. NASA's ESSD has a critical role in implementing three major national directives: Climate Change Research via Climate Change Science Program Global Earth Observation System of Systems via the U.S. Group on Earth Observations (US GEO) Vision for Space Exploration NASA Earth-Sun system science conducts and sponsors research, collects new observations from space, develops technologies and extends science and technology education to learners of all ages. NASA now has a system of spacecraft with the ability to characterize the current state of the Earth-Sun system. In the years ahead, NASA's fleet will evolve into constellations of smart satellites that can be reconfigured based on the changing needs of science and technology. From there we envision an intelligent and integrated observation network composed of sensors deployed in vantage points from the subsurface to deep space. Technical and programmatic details and status of representative Earth-Sun system missions will be presented.
Index Keywords: Earth (planet); Planets; Solar system; Spacecraft; Earth's atmosphere; Earth-Sun System Division (ESSD); Magnetically variable star; Space environment; Space research

Authors: Nelson P.F., Flores A., Francois J.L.
Title: A simplified probabilistic safety assessment of a steam-methane reforming hydrogen production plant coupled to a high-temperature gas cooled nuclear reactor
Source title: American Nuclear Society International Topical Meeting on Probabilistic Safety Analysis, PSA 05
Affiliations: Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Facultad de Ingeniería, Jiutepec, Morelos, 62550, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, P.F., Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Facultad de Ingeniería, Jiutepec, Morelos, 62550, Mexico; Flores, A., Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Facultad de Ingeniería, Jiutepec, Morelos, 62550, Mexico; Francois, J.L., Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Facultad de Ingeniería, Jiutepec, Morelos, 62550, Mexico
Abstract: A Probabilistic Safety Assessment (PSA) is being developed for a steam-methane reforming hydrogen production plant linked to a High-Temperature Gas Cooled Nuclear Reactor (HTGR). This work is based on the Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute's (JAERI) High Temperature Test Reactor (HTTR) prototype in Japan. This study has two major objectives: calculate the risk to onsite and offsite individuals, and calculate the frequency of different types of damage to the complex. A simplified HAZOP study was performed to identify initiating events, based on existing studies. The initiating events presented here are methane pipe break, helium pipe break, and PPWC heat exchanger pipe break. Generic data was used for the fault tree analysis and the initiating event frequency. Saphire was used for the PSA analysis. The results show that the average frequency of an accident at this complex is 2.5×10 -6/year which is divided into the various end states. The dominant sequences result in the end state that causes graphite oxidation, which does not pose a health risk to the population. The dominant sequences that could affect the population are those that result in a methane explosion and occur with a frequency of 6.5×10-8/year, while the other sequences are much less frequent. The health risk presents itself if there are people in the vicinity who could be affected by the explosion. This analysis also demonstrates that an accident in one of the plants has little effect on the other. This is true given the design base distance between the plants, the fact that the reactor is underground, as well as other safety characteristics of the HTGR. Sensitivity studies are being performed in order to determine where additional and improved data is needed.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Nuclear reactors; Probability; Risk assessment; Software prototyping; Trees (mathematics); Health risk; Heat exchanger pipe break; High Temperature Test Reactor (HTTR); Probabilistic Safety Assessment (PSA); Industrial plants

Authors: Nesje A., Jansen E., Birks H.J.B., Bjune A.E., Bakke J., Andersson C., Dahl S.O., Kristensen D.K., Lauritzen S.-E., Lie Ø., Risebrobakken B., Svendsen J.-I.
Title: Holocene climate variability in the northern North Atlantic region: A review of terrestrial and marine evidence
Affiliations: Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Geography, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Biology, University of Bergen, Allegaten 41, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Nesje, A., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Jansen, E., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Birks, H.J.B., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Biology, University of Bergen, Allegaten 41, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Bjune, A.E., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Biology, University of Bergen, Allegaten 41, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Bakke, J., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Geography, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Andersson, C., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Dahl, S.O., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Geography, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Kristensen, D.K., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Lauritzen, S.-E., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Lie, Ø., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Risebrobakken, B., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway; Svendsen, J.-I., Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Department of Earth Science, University of Bergen, Allegaten 55, Bergen, 5007, Norway
Abstract: The Holocene epoch, which followed the last major pulse of glaciation (the Younger Dryas) at the end of the last glaciation, encompasses a period before there was any substantial anthropogenic forcing of climate. A synthesis of climatic development during the Holocene (ca. 11,500 cal. yr BP to the present) is based on pollen-based quantitative temperature reconstructions, tree-line variations, chironomids, tree-ring records, speleothem data, glacier variations, and marine records (stable isotopes, species abundance, lithological changes) from the Nordic Seas. The Holocene has been regarded as a period of relatively stable climate, but recent evidence suggests there have been several significant millennial-scale climate fluctuations (larger than the post mid-19th century warming trend) throughout the Holocene. A general climate warming in the first part of the Holocene was punctuated by a few, abrupt climate reversals, centred at 10,000, 9,700, and 8,200 cal. yr BP. The data suggest there was a period of relatively warm conditions in the first half of the Holocene, in many areas warmer than in the 20th century, after which temperatures generally declined. The temperature decline was punctuated by centennial-scale warmer and colder periods with the most recent cold episode (~AD 1550-1925), including the “Little Ice Age”, being one of the coldest of the entire Holocene. The kind of data presented here can be used for detecting mechanisms and forcing factors behind the reconstructed climate variations and to study leads and lags in the Earth's climate system. A comparison between the climate-forcing factors and the Holocene records presented here suggests that the early Holocene thermal maximum observed in most records from the Nordic Seas region was caused by increased summer solar insolation to the northern Hemisphere. The suborbital millennial to decennial climate variability observed in the Holocene climate reconstructions was most probably a combined effect of solar activity changes, periods of increased explosive volcanism, and internal feedback mechanisms in the Earth’s climate system. Internal modes of the climate system variability (for example, the North Atlantic Oscillation) were most likely responsible for some of the observed climate variability in winter. In addition to external climate-forcing factors, meltwater from the retreating northern hemisphere ice sheets and abrupt, catastrophic lake drainage from ice-marginal lakes during the termination of the last Ice Age had a significant, regional climate impact. In the near future, it will be possible to combine high-resolution palaeo-climatic reconstructions with fully coupled ocean-atmosphere climate models in order to test the complex interactions between the different forcing factors to help explain the primary forcing factors and the accompanying feedbacks behind the observed Holocene climate development in the North Atlantic region. © 2005 by the American Geophysical Union.

Authors: Newton J., Paci C.D.J., Ogden A.
Title: Climate change and natural hazards in Northern Canada: Integrating indigenous perspectives with government policy
Source title: Mitigation of Natural Hazards and Disasters: International Perspectives
Affiliations: John Newton Associates, 262 Robert Street, Toronto, ON M5S 2K8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Newton, J., John Newton Associates, 262 Robert Street, Toronto, ON M5S 2K8, Canada; Paci, C.D.J., John Newton Associates, 262 Robert Street, Toronto, ON M5S 2K8, Canada; Ogden, A., John Newton Associates, 262 Robert Street, Toronto, ON M5S 2K8, Canada
Abstract: A study of the relationship between natural hazards and climate change in the international context provides the background for a discussion of the expected changes. In the context of this global discussion, this paper reviews the current perspectives of those natural hazards that are likely to be influenced by climate change, using northern Canada as a regional case study. The northern implications of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change are examined, including the status of climate change action by the northern territorial governments, the evolving role of indigenous people, and the responsibility for climate change impacts. The difficulties surrounding natural hazards research in remote locations, and the approaches of indigenous people to natural hazards are then presented. The paper concludes with a suggested policy approach for climate change and natural hazards in northern Canada, underscoring the need for more comprehensive adaptive strategies to complement the current tendency to focus on the mitigation of greenhouse gases produced in this region. © 2005 Springer.
Author Keywords: adaptation; climate change; indigenous people; local knowledge; mitigation; natural hazards; northern Canada; policy; traditional knowledge

Authors: Nguyen D.
Title: An alternative solution to post-process mist elimination
Source title: American Filtration and Separations Society 2005 - 18th Annual Conference, AFS 2005
Affiliations: Applications Engineer Kimre, Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, D., Applications Engineer Kimre, Inc., United States
Abstract: In certain industrial applications standard gas treatment methods using waveform chevrons and conventional knitted meshes for mist elimination have not been successful in meeting pollution control requirements. As a result the facilities in question have been required to run at lower capacities or have been forced to use extraordinary emissions abatement treatment methods to meet local and Federal emissions requirements. This paper will use three case histories to discuss the specific operational and emission issues that caused failures, and to draw general conclusions about the efficacy of emissions treatments during the process versus post-process. In each case the emissions problems required correction after construction and commissioning, thereby increasing the overall capital and startup costs. Gas flowrate, velocity and pressure drop will be considered in determining if treatment during the process can be the most effective alternative in meeting emissions standards. This paper will also discuss ways to determine which process designs may be prone to failure in meeting emissions requirements and how changes to those designs can minimize the risk of failure and the need for post-process treatment.
Index Keywords: Alternative solutions; Control requirements; Emissions abatements; Gas treatment; Mist elimination; Risk of failure; Start-up costs; Treatment methods; Industrial applications; Gas emissions

Authors: Nicolai R.E., Lefers R., Pohl S.U.
Title: Configuration of a vertical biofilter
Source title: Livestock Environment VII - Proceedings of the Seventh International Symposium
Affiliations: Agricultural and Biosystems Engineering Department, South Dakota State University, Box 2120, Brookings, SD 57007, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nicolai, R.E., Agricultural and Biosystems Engineering Department, South Dakota State University, Box 2120, Brookings, SD 57007, United States; Lefers, R., Agricultural and Biosystems Engineering Department, South Dakota State University, Box 2120, Brookings, SD 57007, United States; Pohl, S.U., Agricultural and Biosystems Engineering Department, South Dakota State University, Box 2120, Brookings, SD 57007, United States
Abstract: Concerns over odor and gas emissions from livestock production facilities have increased in the United States. Biofilters have been demonstrated to be an effective technology in reducing odor and gas emissions from these facilities. Large biofilter media beds sometimes prevent application of this technology to building layouts. A vertical biofilter may be an effective alternative. The research objective was to determine optimum biofilter construction to achieve uniform airflow as the media settles. Media thickness was determined to be a factor in achieving uniform airflow. For a minimum thick biofilter media of 30 cm, a parallel wall construction produced the least airflow variation. As the media thickness increased to 61 cm, airflow variation across the biofilter was reduced by increasing the taper between the side walls which support the media to 9.6 degrees. Improved media moisture distribution was achieved when the water soaker hose was placed on top of the media versus being suspended vertically through the media. The net value of this research will achieve a more efficient vertical biofilter.
Author Keywords: Biofilters; Emissions; Odor; Odor abatement; Swine
Index Keywords: Odor abatement; Uniform airflow; Vertical biofilter; Gas emissions; Moisture; Odors; Biofilters

Authors: Nikanjam M.
Title: Current and future diesel fuel issues in the United States
Source title: 9th International Conference on Stability, Handling and Use of Liquid Fuels 2005
Affiliations: Chevron Products Company, 100 Chevron Way, Richmond, CA 94802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nikanjam, M., Chevron Products Company, 100 Chevron Way, Richmond, CA 94802, United States
Abstract: Diesel fuel in the U.S. has been mostly an uneventful product for many years. Due to recent pressure to provide fuels that are compatible with new engine technology to reduce emissions, and to improve performance and sociability of diesel vehicles, a number of changes have been made or are being considered. The potential for the introduction of light-duty diesel vehicles also has created challenges that are unique to the U.S. This presentation summarizes the cultural differences between the U.S. and other regions of the world such as Europe, and will list fuel properties and issues that need to be considered as a necessary part of a transition from business as usual to the new and more challenging environment.
Index Keywords: Business-as-usual; Cultural difference; Diesel vehicles; Engine technology; Fuel properties; Light-duty; Diesel locomotives; Liquid fuels; Diesel fuels

Authors: Nilsen C.N., Nowak E., Sorgi K., Zhang X.
Title: Environmental challenges and processes for early research & development - A case study
Authors with affiliations: Nilsen, C.N.; Nowak, E.; Sorgi, K.; Zhang, X.
Abstract: Johnson & Johnson has committed through its famous Credo to protect the environment. Using a multi-faceted approach, we are constantly assessing our capacity to reduce emissions and minimize waste in a manner that exceeds current federal and state standards. Although the amounts of chemicals used in manufacturing are greater than those used in Research & Development, the breadth of chemicals used is much greater in R&D which can make environmental modeling more difficult. A research and development facility used to prepare APIs for use in First-In-Human clinical trials in the State of New Jersey will be used as a case study. Processes such as Pilot Plant permitting, internal and external environmental assessment, and engineering controls will be discussed. In addition, examples will be given to show how we have been reducing waste by as much as 90% on certain projects and maintaining emissions at less than 10% of our total permitted amount, thus helping to achieve our company's Credo vision.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Industrial emissions; Mathematical models; Process control; Waste management; Environment; Environmental modeling; Research & Development; Research and development management

Authors: Nishoka K., Maeda T., Shimizu M.
Title: Effect of Various In-furnace conditions on blast furnace hearth drainage
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishoka, K., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan; Maeda, T., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan; Shimizu, M., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan
Abstract: Stable blast furnace operation is required to reduce energy consumption and CO2 emission in iron and steelmaking industry. For the stable blast furnace operation, precise controlled drainage is one of the important factors. Therefore, in this work, the effect of coke diameter, void fraction, coke diameter distribution, coke free space, impermeable zone, slag viscosity in a blast furnace hearth on drainage rates, gas-slag and slag-iron interfaces shapes and maximum gas-slag interfaces height were examined with a three-dimensional mathematical model. The results indicate that the conditions of the peripheral region at the taphole level determine the residual slag volume. The packed bed in the region 2.0 m from the taphole has about 50% of contribution to the residual slag volume. The void fraction change has the largest effect on the gas-slag interfaces height. The coke diameter distribution has little effect on the total drainage rate as well as the coke diameter of the uniform packed bed, coke free space, and impermeable zone bellow the taphole level. The taphole conditions dominate the total drainage rate under the terms of the assumed blast furnace conditions. The conditions of the peripheral region in the hearth determine the drainage rate patterns of the iron and slag. The peripheral region's permeability can be predicted from the drainage rate patterns of iron and slag, if precise measurement of the drainage rate patterns can be achieved. A drainage pattern, whether iron drains prior to slag or slag drains prior to iron, is largely affected by a drainage interval. © 2005 ISIJ.
Author Keywords: Blast furnace hearth; Coke diameter; Iron and slag flow; Ironmaking; Numerical simulation; Residual slag volume; Slag viscosity; VOF method; Void fraction
Index Keywords: Coke; Computer simulation; Drainage; Iron metallography; Slags; Viscosity; Blast furnace hearth; Iron and slag flow; Ironmaking; Slag viscosity; VOF method; Void fraction; Blast furnaces

Authors: Nogueira R.D.C.C., Slama J.G.
Title: Implementing the balanced approach for airport noise control in developing countries: The case of Brazil
Source title: International Congress on Noise Control Engineering 2005, INTERNOISE 2005
Affiliations: Laboratory of Vibration and Acoustics/PEM/COPPE, Federal University of Rio Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 21945-970, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Nogueira, R.D.C.C., Laboratory of Vibration and Acoustics/PEM/COPPE, Federal University of Rio Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 21945-970, Brazil; Slama, J.G., Laboratory of Vibration and Acoustics/PEM/COPPE, Federal University of Rio Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 21945-970, Brazil
Abstract: The ICAO on the 33rd OACI assembly in October 2001 has defined a philosophy resolution about Airport Noise Control called "Balanced Approach", with the following four courses of action: Noise reduction on the source (aircraft), land-use planning and management around airports, operational procedures limiting noise emission and operations restrictions. With respect to this last issue, the most common actions adopted in many countries are the prohibition of the noisiest aircraft and the limitation of the number of night flights. However, in many developing countries, such as Brazil, a lot of difficulties remain: the noisiest aircraft are still operating in major airports, even at night time, while local and national regulations relative to noise emission are not harmonized so that noise reduction actions are impaired. The Airport Noise Study Group from Federal University of Rio de Janeiro - GERA/LAVI/COPPE/UFRJ - is developing studies and methods relative to the introduction of the Balanced Approach for Airport Noise Control in Brazil. These studies include the classification of the Brazilian airports with respect to the magnitude of noise impact and around them, noise contour sensibility studies considering land use and occupation around airports and the analysis of the adequacy and coherence of regulations about noise control. This communication reports these studies, showing their complementarities and respective importance for the successful introduction of the Balanced Approach in Brazil.
Index Keywords: Airport noise; Courses of actions; Land-use planning; Night time; Noise contours; Noise emissions; Noise impact; Operational procedures; Study Groups; Acoustic emissions; Acoustic variables control; Developing countries; Land use; Noise abatement; Noise pollution; Airports

Authors: Novak J.S.
Title: Supercritical carbon dioxide sterilization of liquid foods using a membrane system
Authors with affiliations: Novak, J.S.
Abstract: Supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO2) at greater than 31.1°C and pressures exceeding 7.38 MPa exists in a dense liquid state where the CO2 retains the lower surface tension of a gaseous phase and the increased solubility of a liquid phase. This supercritical state enables CO 2 to extract various organic and inorganic molecules while inactivating numerous microorganisms. This technology has been enhanced using a microporous polypropylene membrane contactor system to saturate pumpable liquids rapidly with dense CO2. The dense CO2 is continuously recirculated without depressurization. The nonthermal process effectively inactivated a wide range of spoilage and pathogenic vegetative microorganisms, while spore-forming microorganisms required temperatures exceeding 45°C following membrane CO2 saturation. Desired changes in product flow rates necessitated consistent control of CO2 supply in order to balance the required product microbial reductions. The (scCO2) process was found to be non-toxic to the food being processed, capable of retaining fresh juice flavors, economic, and without solvent disposal problems.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Food processing; Fruit juices; Microorganisms; Polymeric membranes; Polypropylenes; Solvents; Sterilization (cleaning); Surface tension; Dense liquid state; Microporous polypropylene; Pumpable liquids; Supercritical carbon dioxide; Food products

Authors: Ntziachristos L., Giechaskiel B., Pistikopoulos P., Samaras Z.
Title: Comparative assessment of two different sampling systems for particle emission type-approval measurements
Affiliations: Laboratory of Applied Thermodynamics, Aristotle University Thessaloniki, GR-54124 Thessaloniki, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Ntziachristos, L., Laboratory of Applied Thermodynamics, Aristotle University Thessaloniki, GR-54124 Thessaloniki, Greece; Giechaskiel, B., Laboratory of Applied Thermodynamics, Aristotle University Thessaloniki, GR-54124 Thessaloniki, Greece; Pistikopoulos, P., Laboratory of Applied Thermodynamics, Aristotle University Thessaloniki, GR-54124 Thessaloniki, Greece; Samaras, Z., Laboratory of Applied Thermodynamics, Aristotle University Thessaloniki, GR-54124 Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: The Particle Measurement Programme (PMP), initiated from different Member States, aims at developing a method and sampling recommendations for a particle number-based emission standard, to support future emission regulation in Europe. In this paper we applied two different commercially available dilution systems (an FPS from Dekati Ltd and an MD19-2E from Matter Engineering AG) to record the particle emissions of a Euro II and a Euro III diesel passenger car. The latter was also fitted with a diesel particle filter (DPF) to simulate future emission levels. At their present development stage, both dilution systems failed to totally comply with all requirements of the PMP protocol. The main problems appeared to be the lack of accurate determination of the dilution ratio and the inability to reach the desired dilution temperature. However, they were able to eliminate nucleation mode particles and the results demonstrated that particle number concentration measurement is equally repeatable to the gravimetric method for the Euro III vehicle and even more so for the DPF one. Over the type-approval cycle, the Euro III vehicle was found to consistently emit below 1014 km-1 particles without a DPF and 1011 km-1 particles with the DPF. The exact level could only be determined with external dilution ratio determination. These results suggest that it is possible to repeatably measure the particle number emissions but some additional refinements are still needed to today's technical solutions to meet the demanding requirements of type-approval measurements. Copyright © 2005 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Automotive engineering; Comparative assessment; Diesel passenger cars; Emission regulation; Gravimetric methods; Nucleation mode particles; Particle measurement; Particle number concentration; Particle number emission; Dilution

Authors: Nunes-Nesi A., Carrari F., Lytovchenko A., Smith A.M.O., Loureiro M.E., Ratcliffe R.G., Sweetlove L.J., Fernie A.R.
Title: Enhanced photosynthetic performance and growth as a consequence of decreasing mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase activity in transgenic tomato plants
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Molekulare Pflanzenphysiologie, 14476 Golm, Germany; Department of Plant Sciences, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3RB, United Kingdom; Departamento de Biologia Vegetal, Universidade Federal de Viçosa, Viçosa-Minas Gerais, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Nunes-Nesi, A., Max-Planck-Institut für Molekulare Pflanzenphysiologie, 14476 Golm, Germany; Carrari, F., Max-Planck-Institut für Molekulare Pflanzenphysiologie, 14476 Golm, Germany; Lytovchenko, A., Max-Planck-Institut für Molekulare Pflanzenphysiologie, 14476 Golm, Germany; Smith, A.M.O., Department of Plant Sciences, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3RB, United Kingdom; Loureiro, M.E., Departamento de Biologia Vegetal, Universidade Federal de Viçosa, Viçosa-Minas Gerais, Brazil; Ratcliffe, R.G., Department of Plant Sciences, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3RB, United Kingdom; Sweetlove, L.J., Department of Plant Sciences, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3RB, United Kingdom; Fernie, A.R., Max-Planck-Institut für Molekulare Pflanzenphysiologie, 14476 Golm, Germany
Abstract: Transgenic tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) plants expressing a fragment of the mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase gene in the antisense orientation and exhibiting reduced activity of this isoform of malate dehydrogenase show enhanced photosynthetic activity and aerial growth under atmospheric conditions (360 ppm CO2). In comparison to wild-type plants, carbon dioxide assimilation rates and total plant dry matter were up to 11% and 19% enhanced in the transgenics, when assessed on a whole-plant basis. Accumulation of carbohydrates and redox-related compounds such as ascorbate was also markedly elevated in the transgenics. Also increased in the transgenic plants was the capacity to use L-galactono-lactone, the terminal precursor of ascorbate biosynthesis, as a respiratory substrate. Experiments in which ascorbate was fed to isolated leaf discs also resulted in increased rates of photosynthesis providing strong indication for an ascorbate-mediated link between the energy-generating processes of respiration and photosynthesis. This report thus shows that the repression of this mitochondrially localized enzyme improves both carbon assimilation and aerial growth in a crop species. © 2005 American Society of Plant Biologists.

Authors: Nunez E., Nunez S.A., Fouad F.H.
Title: Sustainability in Autoclaved Aerated Concrete (AAC) construction
Source title: Autoclaved Aerated Concrete Innovation and Development - Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Autoclaved Aerated Concrete
Affiliations: Southern Company Generation, Birmingham, AL, United States; University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nunez, E., Southern Company Generation, Birmingham, AL, United States; Nunez, S.A., University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, United States; Fouad, F.H., University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, United States
Abstract: Sustainability is a new trend in the construction industry intended to minimize environmental impact by reducing resource consumption, emissions, and waste production. Sustainability also implies recycling of materials after their use. Autoclaved aerated concrete AAC, originally introduced in Sweden in the late 1920s, is a lightweight material with no coarse aggregate, produced by mixing cement, lime, sand or fly ash, aluminum powder and water. In the United States, the use of AAC has been somewhat limited due to marketing conditions, lack of applicable building codes, lack of familiarity with design methodologies, and limited understanding of the advantages of AAC by the design and construction industry. This paper provides a review of the issues associated with the use of AAC in comparison to other construction materials from a sustainability perspective, with the intent of providing further information to highlight the advantages of AAC as an environmentally friendly material. © 2005 Taylor & Francis Group.

Authors: Nutalapati D., Gupta R., Moghtaderi B., Wall T.F.
Title: Transformations of alkalis in biomass combustion
Source title: 5th Asia-Pacific Conference on Combustion, ASPACC 2005: Celebrating Prof. Bob Bilger's 70th Birthday
Affiliations: Discipline of Chemical Engineering, University of Newcastle, NSW 2308, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Nutalapati, D., Discipline of Chemical Engineering, University of Newcastle, NSW 2308, Australia; Gupta, R., Discipline of Chemical Engineering, University of Newcastle, NSW 2308, Australia; Moghtaderi, B., Discipline of Chemical Engineering, University of Newcastle, NSW 2308, Australia; Wall, T.F., Discipline of Chemical Engineering, University of Newcastle, NSW 2308, Australia
Abstract: In search for a fuel that can serve as an alternative to fossil fuels and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the renewable nature of biomass fuels (wood based, agricultural byproducts, urban green waste) places it among the attractive options. However, the alkali (K and Na) behaviour in biomass fuels is of major concern for its use in power generation. Unlike coal, in biomass combustion most of the alkali matter evaporates from the fuel and forms alkali sulphates and chlorides based on availability of sulphur and chlorine. Alkali matter in the form of alkali sulphates and chlorides causes deposits in the heat transfer part of the boiler and forms sub-micron ash that can cause environmental problems. In the past, studies have been conducted to understand the release mechanism of alkalis from biomass fuels, gas phase transformations and deposition. It was found that alkali release and transformations depends on various factors like fuel composition, operating conditions and the combustion system chosen for conversion. This paper summarizes the work done to understand the alkali behaviour in biomass fuels during combustion. In addition, the paper discusses the attempts made to minimize the alkali effects in biomass combustion.
Index Keywords: Agricultural by-products; Alternative to fossil fuels; Biomass combustion; Combustion systems; Environmental problems; Operating condition; Release mechanism; Urban green wastes; Boiler deposits; Byproducts; Chlorine compounds; Coal combustion; Gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; Wood fuels; Biomass

Authors: Oda J., Matsuhashi R., Yoshida Y.
Title: The decision to invest in emissions reduction technologies based on the real options approach
Affiliations: University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oda, J., University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Matsuhashi, R., University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Yoshida, Y., University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This chapter focuses on a study that illustrates the way uncertainty and social costs can influence a firm's decision to invest in an emission reduction technology. For a case study, this study considers a firm owing aged coal-fired thermal power plants in the United States. The firm has an option to invest in an Integrated coal Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) no capture plant, IGCC capture plant, or Natural Gas Combined Cycle (NGCC) for the substitution of the aged power plants. The optimal investment behavior subject to stochastic CO2 emission allowance price, natural gas price, and social cost is calculated numerically in the study by using the Bellman equation and lattice models with few variables. The results show that not only CO2 emission allowance price and natural gas price but also social costs and their uncertainty influence the firm's decision to invest in capture plant, especially at an early date. It is suggested that direct subsidies from government to the firm's capital cost are worthwhile, but social preference that forms the characteristic of the social costs could be a key issue in a firm's decision for the investment in an emission reduction technology. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Oetelaar G.A., Beaudoin A.B.
Title: Darkened skies and sparkling grasses: The potential impact of the Mazama ash fall on the northwestern Plains
Affiliations: Department of Archaeology, University of Calgary, 2500 University Drive, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada; Royal Alberta Museum, 12845-102nd Avenue, Edmonton, Alta. T5N 0M6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oetelaar, G.A., Department of Archaeology, University of Calgary, 2500 University Drive, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada; Beaudoin, A.B., Royal Alberta Museum, 12845-102nd Avenue, Edmonton, Alta. T5N 0M6, Canada
Abstract: Mazama ash has long served as an important chronostratigraphic marker for archaeologists working on the northwestern Plains. Despite its thickness and widespread distribution, few archaeologists have examined the potential impact of the ash fall on the plant, animal, and human communities of the area. To some extent, the failure to explore the consequences of this natural disaster reflects the paucity of historical documentation and the lack of current research on the impacts of volcanic eruptions on human communities. The 1980 eruption of Mount St Helens has prompted a renewed interest in the study of volcanoes, including their impacts on climate, plants, animals, and humans. The potential impact of the Mazama ash fall on the climate, ecology, and human populations of the northwestern Plains is explored in light of this current research.
Author Keywords: Archaeology; Climate; Disasters; Mazama ash; Volcanoes

Authors: Ogoni H.A.
Title: Design of a high rate anaerobic digester for the production of methane-A case study of port-harcourt municipality (Nigeria)
Affiliations: Dept of Chemical/Petrochemical Engineering, Rivers State University of Science and Technology, P.M.B. 5080, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ogoni, H.A., Dept of Chemical/Petrochemical Engineering, Rivers State University of Science and Technology, P.M.B. 5080, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Abstract: Mathematical models for the design of a high rate anaerobic digester for the production of methane were developed and tested for Port Harcourt municipality. Domestic solid wastes were used as a feed stock, considering the growing energy need and environmental concern as it affects the developing countries. The digester was designed to treat 50,000kg/day of domestic solid waste within the limit ofsolubilization rate constant Ks = 0.1 to 0.4 degree of conversion of biodegradable particulate α = 0.1 to 0.9 and at operating temperature of 40°C. Computer simulation of the different reactor environment was carried out using a C-programming language software developed for this purpose. Results obtained from computation include: reactor dimensions, hydraulic retention time, effluent waste concentrations and methane production.

Authors: Oh N.-H., Kim H.-S., Richter Jr. D.D.
Title: What regulates soil CO2 concentrations? A modeling approach to CO2 diffusion in deep soil profiles
Affiliations: Nicholas Sch. Environ./Earth Sci., Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Sch. of Forest. and Environ. Studies, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oh, N.-H., Nicholas Sch. Environ./Earth Sci., Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States, Sch. of Forest. and Environ. Studies, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, United States; Kim, H.-S., Nicholas Sch. Environ./Earth Sci., Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Richter Jr., D.D., Nicholas Sch. Environ./Earth Sci., Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Abstract: About 10% of the CO2 in the above-ground atmosphere is annually recycled back to the atmosphere from the soil. Soil respiration (the sum of root and microbial respiration) increases soil CO2 concentrations by 10- to 100-fold or more than that in the above-ground atmosphere, and such elevated concentrations have a variety of significant effects on soil systems. Because increased soil respiration is expected to result from future global climates, due both to elevated atmospheric CO2 and temperature, we developed a multibox model without steady-state assumptions to investigate the factors that regulate soil CO2 concentrations. Results suggest that below-ground CO2 concentrations are predominantly controlled by tortuosity of pores, depth distributions of root and microbial activity, and total production of soil CO2. Considering the dependence of soil respiration rates on climate, our results are significant in suggesting that future climate change will increase soil CO2 concentrations in direct proportion to increases of below-ground respiration.
Author Keywords: CO2; Diffusion; Modeling; Respiration; Soil
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Concentration (process); Mathematical models; Microbiology; Soils; Global climates; Microbial activity; Soil respiration; Soil systems; Earth atmosphere; carbon dioxide; article; atmosphere; carbon dioxide measurement; climate; diffusion; microbial activity; model; soil respiration; steady state

Authors: Oida A., Nakashima H., Miyasaka J., Ohdoi K., Matsumoto H., Shinohara N.
Title: Development of a new type electric off-road vehicle by means of microwave power transmission in the air
Source title: 15th International Conference of the International Society for Terrain Vehicle Systems 2005, ISTVS 2005
Affiliations: Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan; Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Kyoto University, Uji 611-0011, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oida, A., Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan; Nakashima, H., Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan; Miyasaka, J., Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan; Ohdoi, K., Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan; Matsumoto, H., Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Kyoto University, Uji 611-0011, Japan; Shinohara, N., Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere, Kyoto University, Uji 611-0011, Japan
Abstract: Needless to say, we are now facing to a critical state of global environment, that is a global warming. We have to change our thinking way and economic system from those that depend on fossil resource to those that depend on solar resource called natural energy. In our research field everybody will imagine that an electric vehicle is the best one in order to diminish or reduce carbon dioxide exhaust. The battery is not adequate as an energy source for electric vehicles, because the battery will soon be dead due to its low energy density and low power density. The fuel cell is more favorable than the battery, but the mass of fuel cell is still big and the fuel cell can only be replaced the internal combustion engine, so that the power transmission devices are still necessary. The new concept electric off-road vehicle proposed here is entirely different from above ones. The vehicle has neither combustion engine nor battery, but it has only electric motors. The energy to drive the motors is transmitted in the air as microwave of 2.45 GHz. This technology was developed as a transmitting method of electricity from a large-scale solar power station (SPS) in the space to the earth at the Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere of Kyoto University. We have constructed some models of electric off-road vehicle and investigated the adoptability of microwave power transmission for the vehicle. In this paper some experimental results of microwave power transmission to drive the vehicles are presented and some problems such as energy transmission efficiency are also discussed.
Author Keywords: Environmental protection; Microwave power transmission; Zero emission vehicle

Title: Self-alignment technologies of organic electronic devices and its integrated panels
Source title: Journal of Photopolymer Science and Technology

Abstract: Self-alignment (SA) technologies and multiple integration of organic electronic devices are introduced. For obtaining higher device performance, self-alignment technology is effective. For example, SA organic field effect transistor (OFET) can be realized using back surface exposure for gate electrode as a mask and lift-off technique for formation of source/ drain regions. Another self alignment technology under study is formation of emission region in organic light emitting diode (OLED) using ink-jet printing (UP) technique, where ink jet printed dot becomes emission region. In the case of multiple integration technology, face-to-face emission panel named "Dual Drive & Emission Panel (DDE)" with stacked two set OLED with common scan line and two set of data lines and combination of emission and photo detection named "Bi-Function Matrix Panel (Bi-Matrix)" with stacked OLED and organic photodiode (OPD) can be realized. These approaches will be expected for novel application. © 2005 TAPJ.
Author Keywords: Organic light emitting diode; Organic photodiode; Organic transistor; Self-alignment

Authors: Okamine N., Sugimachi H., Nakamuta K., Jinno K.
Title: Treatment of tributyltin contaminated marine sediments, experiments and modeling
Source title: 31st IAHR Congress 2005: Water Engineering for the Future, Choices and Challenges
Affiliations: Dept. of Urban and Environmental Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Civil Engineering Course, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan; Fukuoka City Institute for Hygiene and Environment, Jigyohama 2-1-34, Chuo-ku, Fukuoka, 810-0065, Japan; Institute of Environmental Systems, Graduate School of Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Okamine, N., Dept. of Urban and Environmental Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Civil Engineering Course, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan; Sugimachi, H., Dept. of Urban and Environmental Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Civil Engineering Course, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan; Nakamuta, K., Fukuoka City Institute for Hygiene and Environment, Jigyohama 2-1-34, Chuo-ku, Fukuoka, 810-0065, Japan; Jinno, K., Institute of Environmental Systems, Graduate School of Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan
Abstract: Preliminary experiments and modeling were studied for a pilot plant of Tributyltin(TBT) contaminated sediments in prospect of a sequential treatment system. Flocculation test by four kinds of coagulant showed that PSI-100 is better than the other agents and that its optimal amount of applied coagulant was 0.3 mL/L. The prototype treatment plant consisted of filtration by polyethylene fiber sheet, sand and activated carbon was tested in order to know the decrease in the TBT concentration through the filtering materials. The experiment showed that the outlet TBT concentration can be optimally controlled by designing the length of each material taking account for their cost. A quantitative evaluation that can reflect local conditions, for example, societal, geographical, and environmental characteristics, becomes indispensable for the systematic treatment when remediation of marine environment is planned. In order to satisfy these demands, the sensitivity analysis for a mathematical model was done. It was concluded that the adopted mathematical is applicable for designing the efficient treatment plant. © 31st IAHR Congress 2005: Water Engineering for the Future, Choices and Challenges. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: Absorption; Coagulation; Filtration; Marine sediment pollution; Treatment System; Tributyltin
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Coagulation; Insecticides; Pilot plants; Sensitivity analysis; Submarine geology; Contaminated marine sediments; Contaminated sediment; Efficient treatment; Environmental characteristic; Filtering materials; Polyethylene fibers; Quantitative evaluation; Sequential treatments; Activated carbon treatment

Authors: Olberding J., Beyerlein D.C.S., Steciak J., Cherry M.
Title: Dynamometer testing of an ethanol-water fueled transit van
Affiliations: University of Idaho, Mechanical Engineering, Moscow, ID 83844, United States; Automotive Resources, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Olberding, J., University of Idaho, Mechanical Engineering, Moscow, ID 83844, United States; Beyerlein, D.C.S., University of Idaho, Mechanical Engineering, Moscow, ID 83844, United States; Steciak, J., University of Idaho, Mechanical Engineering, Moscow, ID 83844, United States; Cherry, M., Automotive Resources, Inc.
Abstract: Previous research using catalytic igniters and ethanol water fueled mixtures has shown potential for lowering CO and NOx emissions while increasing engine efficiency over conventional engine configurations. Catalytic ignition systems allow combustion initiation over a much wider range of stoichiometry and water composition than traditional spark ignition systems. The platform explored in this research is a transit van converted to operate on either gasoline or ethanol water fuel mixtures. Special attention was devoted to improve cold starting and installing additional on board sensors and equipment for future testing. System features include integration of a wide band oxygen sensor, state-of-the-art engine management system, exhaust gas temperature sampling using platinum thin film resistive temperature devices and variable voltage control of catalytic igniters using DC-DC boost converters. The platform explored in this research is a transit van converted to operate on either gasoline or ethanol water fuel mixtures. Special attention was devoted to improve cold starting and installing additional on board sensors and equipment for future testing. System features include integration of a wide band oxygen sensor, state-of-the-art engine management system, exhaust gas temperature sampling using platinum thin film resistive temperature devices, and variable voltage control of catalytic igniters using DC-DC boost converters. Extensive engine performance and emissions testing for 70% ethanol 30% water fuel mixtures operating at air to fuel ratios (AFR) of λ = 1 and λ = 1.15 have shown a substantial reduction in NOx and CO emissions without the use of exhaust after treatment compared to gasoline emissions. Lean mixtures also show reduced emissions and increased thermal efficiency compared to stoichiometric conditions. Chassis dynamometer tests comparing thermal efficiency, and brake specific emissions of NOx, CO2, CO, and hydrocarbons for the ethanol-water fuel mixtures over a wide range of operating conditions are shown. Copyright © 2005 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Catalytic converters; Dynamometers; Efficiency; Electric inverters; Ethanol; Exhaust gases; Gasoline; Ignition; Ignition systems; Mixtures; Nitrogen oxides; Oxygen sensors; Platinum; Powertrains; Thin film circuits; Thin films; Voltage control; Chassis dynamometer tests; DC-DC boost converters; Engine management systems; Exhaust aftertreatment; Exhaust gas temperatures; NOx and CO emission; Substantial reduction; Variable voltage control; DC-DC converters

Authors: Olson R.
Title: Bolivia: Risky business
Authors with affiliations: Olson, R.
Abstract: Bolivia appears to be on a collision course with foreign investors in its oil and gas sector. President Carlos Mesa has been pushing for a compromise that would reduce the effect of the tax increases, but the government may have a difficult time convincing the opposition parties that control Congress, as well as many of Bolivia's people, that foreign investors deserve a break. The proposed Hydrocarbons Law will reverse some of the 1996 reforms. The biggest change is a new 32% tax on oil and gas production that will be added to the existing 18% royalty rate already paid by producers. The bill also enhances the status of YPFB, the state-owned oil company, which was largely reduced to the role of a regulator under the 1996 law. BG, the second-largest holder of reserves in the country, is in a better position to weather the Bolivian storm as the remainder of its portfolio is far more balanced. Nevertheless, the company has a significant stake in Bolivia's future given that it has reserves of 4 tcf of gas and 170 million bbl of liquids in the country. BG produces some 72.5 million cu ft/day of gas in Bolivia, which is shipped to customers in Brazil. Brazil has already begun to signal its unhappiness with the new bill. Petrobras has been planning a 20% increase in the capacity of the 3150 km Gasbol Bolivia-to-Brazil gas pipeline to 1.2 bcf/day as part of its plan to meet the expected doubling in Brazilian gas demand by 2010.

Authors: Ordónez C., Mathis H., Furger M., Henne S., Hüglin C., Staehelin J., Prévǒt A.S.H.
Title: Changes of daily surface ozone maxima in Switzerland in all seasons from 1992 to 2002 and discussion of summer 2003
Affiliations: Laboratory of Atmospheric Chemistry, Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland; Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Testing and Research, Überlandstr. 129, CH-8600 Dübendorf, Switzerland; Institute for Atmospheric and Climate Science, ETH-Hönggerberg, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Ordónez, C., Laboratory of Atmospheric Chemistry, Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland; Mathis, H., Laboratory of Atmospheric Chemistry, Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland; Furger, M., Laboratory of Atmospheric Chemistry, Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland; Henne, S., Laboratory of Atmospheric Chemistry, Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland; Hüglin, C., Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Testing and Research, Überlandstr. 129, CH-8600 Dübendorf, Switzerland; Staehelin, J., Institute for Atmospheric and Climate Science, ETH-Hönggerberg, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland; Prévǒt, A.S.H., Laboratory of Atmospheric Chemistry, Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: An Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA) was used to derive the influence of the meteorological variability on the daily maximum ozone concentrations at 12 low-elevation sites north of the Alps in Switzerland during the four seasons in the 1992-2002 period. The afternoon temperature and the morning global radiation were the variables that accounted for most of the meteorological variability in summer and spring, while other variables that can be related to vertical mixing and dilution of primary pollutants (afternoon global radiation, wind speed, stability or day of the week) were more significant in winter. In addition, the number of days after a frontal passage was important to account for ozone build-up in summer and ozone destruction in winter. The statistical model proved to be a robust tool for reducing the impact of the meteorological variability on the ozone concentrations. The explained variance of the model, averaged over all stations, ranged from 60.2% in winter to 71.9% in autumn. The year-to-year variability of the seasonal medians of daily ozone maxima was reduced by 85% in winter, 60% in summer, and 50% in autumn and spring after the meteorological adjustment. For most stations, no significantly negative trends (at the 95% confidence level) of the summer medians of daily O3 Or Ox (O3+NO2) maxima were found despite the significant reduction in the precursor emissions in Central Europe. However, significant downward trends in the summer 90th percentiles of daily Ox maxima were observed at 6 sites in the region around Zürich (on average -0.73 ppb yr-1 for those sites). The lower effect of the titration by NO as a consequence of the reduced emissions could partially explain the significantly positive O3 trends in the cold seasons (on average 0.69 ppb yr-1 in winter and 0.58 ppb yr-1 in autumn). The increase of Ox found for most stations in autumn (on average 0.23 ppb yr-1) and winter (on average 0.39 ppb yr-1) could be due to increasing European background ozone levels, in agreement with other studies. The statistical model was also able to explain the very high ozone concentrations in summer 2003, the warmest summer in Switzerland for at least ∼150 years. On average, the measured daily ozone maximum was 15 ppb (nearly 29%) higher than in the reference period summer 1992-2002, corresponding to an excess of 5 standard deviations of the summer means of daily ozone maxima in that period. © 2005 Author(s). This work is licensed under a Creative Commons License.

Authors: Orecchini F., Bocci E., Di Carlo A.
Title: Process simulation of a neutral emission plant using chestnut's coppice gasification and Molten Carbonated Fuel Cell
Source title: Proceedings of the 1st European Fuel Cell Technology and Applications Conference 2005 - Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: University of Rome La Sapienza, Italy; CIRPS, University of Rome La Sapienza, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Orecchini, F., University of Rome La Sapienza, Italy; Bocci, E., CIRPS, University of Rome La Sapienza, Italy; Di Carlo, A., CIRPS, University of Rome La Sapienza, Italy
Abstract: The consistent problem of the CO2 emissions and the necessity to find new energy sources, are motivating the scientific research to use high efficiency electrical energy production's technologies that can use renewable energy sources too. The process simulations of advanced plants fed by biomass are a central step to develop biomass and high temperature fuel cells applications. This paper shows the results obtained by the simulation of a particular power plant mainly composed of a gasifier, a Molten Carbonated Fuel Cell at top of a microturbine and feed by chestnut's coppice, available in great quantity in Lazio region. The gasifier produce a gas with a high content of hydrogen and little content of char. This syngas is cleaned, via a hot gas conditioning, reformed, via an autothermal, plate reformer, and sent to the MCFC. The microturbine using the MCFC exhaust gases produce the power necessary to move the air compressor and furthermore electrical energy. Particular models for the MCFC, burner/reformer and gasifier were developed in Fortran and then interfaced in the commercial software (Chemead©) to simulate the plant's thermodynamic behaviour. The results show a possible plant configuration with high carbon conversion and electrical efficiency and very low emissions.
Index Keywords: Electrical energy production; Gas conditioning; High temperature fuel cells; Molten Carbonated Fuel Cells; Biomass; Carbonates; Computer simulation; Energy conversion; Energy efficiency; Gasification; Molten materials; Fuel cells

Authors: Organisciak M., Cavallaro G., Lubrecht A.A.
Title: Starved hydrodynamic lubrication of the piston ring cylinder liner contact: Preliminary study of the influence of surface texturing
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Mécanique des Contacts et des Solides, INSA de Lyon, UMR CNRS 5514, France; PSA Peugeot Citroën, Vélizy Villacoublay, France
Authors with affiliations: Organisciak, M., Laboratoire de Mécanique des Contacts et des Solides, INSA de Lyon, UMR CNRS 5514, France; Cavallaro, G., PSA Peugeot Citroën, Vélizy Villacoublay, France; Lubrecht, A.A., Laboratoire de Mécanique des Contacts et des Solides, INSA de Lyon, UMR CNRS 5514, France
Abstract: Some of the most important challenges concerning automotive engine research are related to the reduction of fuel consumption, the increase of oil drainage intervals and the respect of the environment by a reduction of exhaust emissions. These improvements should not impair engine reliability. On the contrary, the operational life of the engine should increase. These demands are conflicting and a compromise has to be found. This compromise requires a thorough comprehension of the fundamentals of friction generation and oil consumption in an automotive engine and in particular of the piston ring - cylinder liner contact. The surface roughness of a cylinder liner influences these two parameters. Nowadays, surface roughness is imposed by the machining process. But the surface topography can be improved by laser texturing. The current paper describes a transient analysis of a textured starved contact under pure rolling conditions. It shows the influence of the surface texture on oil thickness and pressure profile. Even if a piston ring contact operates under pure sliding conditions, these results allow the understanding of the possible interest of a textured surface. Steady state results for a smooth surface under pure sliding starved conditions are also presented in order to show a particular effect of sliding on the lubricant layer. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Osorio A.A.
Title: Air quality impact due to the "CT Valle de Mexico" power plant repowering
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Comisión Federal de Electricidad, Col Cuauhtemoc, Del. Cuauhtemoc, Ciudad de Mexico Mexico C.P. 06000, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Osorio, A.A., Comisión Federal de Electricidad, Col Cuauhtemoc, Del. Cuauhtemoc, Ciudad de Mexico Mexico C.P. 06000, Mexico
Abstract: The CT Valle de Mexico power plant is located in Estado de Mexico in the vicinity of the Mexico City Metropolitan Zone (ZMCM), this power plant consisted of three units (150 Mw each) and one unit of 300 Mw. Since 1990, the power plant has burned natural gas and has made important efforts to diminish its emissions. With the necessity of increasing the supply of electric energy to the ZMCM and considering the useful life of the unit 4 steam generator, the best alternative for CFE was to re-power the unit 4. The repowering of unit 4 consists in three gas turbines of 84 Mw in hybrid cycle that supply 50% of the steam required. The air quality impact due to the CT Valle de Mexico operation was evaluated. A dispersion model called ISC (Industrial Source Complex Model) was applied. The NOx emissions of the gas turbines resulted of the re-powering should be < 67 ppm vol, reducing de NOx emissions of the unit 4 in 20.4 % and improving the air quality in the influence area, in accordance with the results of the simulation study (dispersion of the emissions) and allowing the increase in electric energy availability in an amount of 223 Mw. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 98th AWMA Annual Conference and Exhibition (Minneapolis, MN 6/21-24/2005).

Authors: Paavola J.
Title: Seeking justice: International environmental governance and climate change
Affiliations: Centre for Social and Economic Research (CSERGE), School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich NR4 7TJ, United Kingdom
